In favor of JUnit, its core is pretty flexible and does allow implementing
=
such categories. You will need a custom runner or rules but these can be
pu=
t in a superclass inherited by all tests and then you just stick to
annotat=
ions. It's a pity everyone seems to have their own solution of
course. Here=
's mine -- randomizedtesting uses annotations to mark groups
which can then=
 be enabled or disabled via a designated system property;
this is used for =
various things in practice (@Slow, @Nightly, @AwaitsFix,
@WindowsOnly, cust=
om groups can be added).

http://labs.carrotsearch.com/randomizedtesting.ht=
ml

Here's a relevant snippet of test code showing how to declare and use a=

custom group.
http://goo.gl/VZuBB

Dawid
